abstract.text: A class that provides the infrastructure for managing the interface in a watchOS app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: An interface controller serves the same purpose as a

object in a UIKit app, except that it doesn’t manage any actual views. It runs in your WatchKit extension and remotely manages the behavior associated with an interface controller in your Watch app’s storyboard file. You subclass
and use its methods to configure the elements of your storyboard scene and to respond to interactions with those elements.

Your interface controller code runs locally on the user’s Apple Watch but is separate from the interface that it manages. When you change the value of an interface object in your code, the system forwards the needed information to your Watch app, which makes the corresponding changes onscreen.

When the user interacts with your app content, the system launches your extension and creates the appropriate interface controller objects automatically. Apps use different interface controllers to manage their notification and app interfaces; WatchKit uses the information in your app’s main storyboard file to determine which interface controller to load. Notification scenes are configured specially so that the system can identify them. For your app, WatchKit loads your app’s main interface controller initially, but you may change the initial interface controller at launch time.
When creating an interface controller, WatchKit instantiates the class and calls its

method. You can use this method to initialize variables and load data; however, don’t use it to configure your user interface. The controller’s user interface elements may not be properly initialized when this method runs.
Next, the system calls the
method. If WatchKit passes a valid object to the

method, use the information in that object to customize the initialization process. Also, the controller’s user interface elements are guaranteed to be available at this point. This means that you can safely use this method to configure your user interface.
The
method lets you know when your interface is about to become active. Use the
method to perform any last minute tasks, such as checking for updates to your content; however, don’t use it for your primary initialization.
The
method may be called at times when your interface isn’t yet onscreen. For example, WatchKit may call the method in advance so that you have time to update your content. WatchKit calls the
method to let you know when your interface becomes visible. Similarly, WatchKit calls the
and
methods when your interface moves offscreen again.
An interface controller can make changes to its interface only in the
method, in the
method, and while the interface is active. Once the system calls the
method, it ignores any attempts to change the value of the controller’s interface objects until the system calls the interface controller’s
method again.
In iOS Simulator, WatchKit calls the
method for the current interface controller when you lock the simulator by selecting Hardware > Lock. When you subsequently unlock the simulator, WatchKit calls that interface controller’s
method again. You can use this capability to debug your activation and deactivation code.
Xcode lets you configure information about your interface controller in your storyboard file. The following table lists the attributes you can configure in your storyboard and their meaning.
Attribute
Description
Identifier
The name of the interface controller. Use this name to specify which interface controller to push or present.
Title
The title string assigned to the interface controller. You can set this value programmatically using the
method.
Is Initial Controller

A Boolean indicating whether the object is the app’s root interface controller. Only one interface controller at a time may have this option enabled. This option doesn’t apply to glance or notification interface controllers.
Activity Indicator On Load
A Boolean value that indicates whether the interface controller’s contents are hidden until the
method returns. When you enable this option, the system displays a progress indicator until the
method returns. You might disable this option if your interface contains mostly static information that can be displayed right away.
Always Bounce
A Boolean value that turns off scrolling and allows built-in controls and containers to fill content to the screen edges, regardless of the content-safe area.
Full Screen

A Boolean value that determines whether SpriteKit or SceneKit content can use the full screen. The system hides the status bar but displays the time in the upper-right corner with a gradient behind it, making the time clearly visible against the scene.
Fixed to screen edges

A Boolean value that indicates whether the contents ignore the safe area and minimum layout margins. When you enable this option, the system turns off scrolling, and allows built-in controls and containers to fill content to the screen edges.
Background
The background image displayed behind the scene’s content. The image specified in your storyboard scrolls with your interface controller’s content.
Mode
The content mode for the background image. This mode defines how the background image scales or fills the screen and behaves in the same way as the constants for the
type.
Animate
A Boolean value indicating whether an animated background image starts running its animation automatically after being loaded. Set this option to
if you want the animation to start automatically; set it to
if you prefer to start the animation programmatically.
Color
The background color to be displayed behind the scene’s content.
Insets
The amount of space (in points) to insert between the edges of the interface controller and its content. Select Custom to specify different values for the top, bottom, left, and right edges.
Spacing
Additional spacing (in points) to include between items in the interface controller.
Subclass

when you have a storyboard scene that requires configuration at runtime or that handles user interactions. Typically, you define a custom subclass for each unique storyboard scene that your app manages. In your subclass, define outlets for any interface objects you need to configure and define action methods for responding to interactions with the elements of your storyboard scene.

Most custom interface controllers you use in your app require a custom interface controller subclass. Even glances need an interface controller to update the glance contents. The only storyboard scene that can’t use a custom interface controller is the scene associated with a static notification interface. When implementing an interface controller for your dynamic notification interface, subclass
instead.
Override any methods of the class needed to configure your interface and get it ready to display. Most interface controllers override the
and
methods. Override any other methods that make sense based on your needs.

abstract.text: Options to specify how a view adjusts its content when its size changes.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Build watchOS apps that use features the app delegate monitors or controls, such as background tasks and extended runtime sessions.
An object that defines a portion of an image that you want to call out separately to an assistive app.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether reduced motion is enabled.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether VoiceOver is running.
Tells the interface controller that the reduce motion status has changed.
Tells the interface controller that the VoiceOver status has changed.
An object that encapsulates information about a button displayed in an alert or action sheet.
Constants indicating the styles for standard system alerts.
Constants indicating the quality of audio recordings.
A class that provides the infrastructure for managing the interface in a watchOS app.

Adds an action to the context menu using a system-provided icon.
Adds an action to the context menu using an existing image resource in your Watch app bundle.

Displays the interface controller in the page-based interface.
Tells the system that you are about to start a potentially lengthy update task for your glance.
Removes all programmatically added actions from the context menu.
The frame rectangle used to display your app’s content.
Insets that define the area where it’s safe to display content on the screen.
Returns the context object to pass to the specified interface controller when a button is tapped.
Returns the context object to pass to the specified interface controller when a row in a table is tapped.
Returns the context objects to pass to a page-based set of interface controllers when a button is tapped.
Returns the context objects to pass to a page-based set of interface controllers when a row in a table is tapped.
The object to use when directly tracking crown events.
Tells the interface controller that its view is now onscreen.
Tells the interface controller that its view is no longer active.
Dismisses the current interface controller from the screen.
Dismisses the pass interface controller
Dismisses the audio recording interface controller.
Dismisses the media interface controller.
Dismisses the text input controller without returning any text.
Tells the system that you finished updating your glance content.
Responds to Handoff–related activity.
Returns an initialized interface controller object.
Tells the interface controller that the user has performed a scroll-to-top gesture (for example, tapping the status bar) and that the scrolling animation has finished.
Tells the interface controller that the user has scrolled to the bottom of the interface and that the scrolling animation has finished.
Tells the interface controller that the user has scrolled to the top of the interface and that the scrolling animation has finished.
Invalidates the most recent user activity.
A Boolean value that determines whether haptic feedback coordinates with the appearance of new rows as the user scrolls through a table.
Called to let you know that the specified picker is now receiving input from the Digital Crown.
Called to let you know that the specified picker is no longer receiving input from the Digital Crown.
Called to let you know when the user settles on a value in a picker.
Pops the current interface controller from the screen.
Pops all interface controllers except the app’s initial interface controller.
Displays a modal interface for presenting passes to the user.
Presents an alert or action sheet over the current interface controller.
Display a standard interface for recording audio from the user’s Apple Watch.
Presents a page-based interface modally.
Presents a single interface controller modally.
Presents a page-based interface modally.
Presents a page-based interface modally.
Displays a modal interface for playing the specified media file.
Displays a modal interface for gathering text input from the user.
Displays a modal interface for gathering language-specific text input from the user.
Pushes a new interface controller onto the screen.
Loads the specified interface controllers and rebuilds the app’s page-based interface.
Loads the specified interface controllers and rebuilds the app’s page-based interface.
Loads the specified interface controllers and rebuilds the app’s page-based interface for the given scrolling orientation.
Scrolls the specified object to the given position onscreen.
Sets the title of the interface.
Leading and trailing insets that represent the minimum layout margins for text elements.
Called to let you know that the user selected a row in the table.
Registers the current user activity with the system.
Registers the current user activity with the system.
Tells the interface controller that the system is about to activate its view.
Tells the interface controller that its view is now offscreen.
An object that provides information that is common to all interface objects in your watchOS app.
Onscreen scroll positions.

An interface controller object that manages a dynamic user interface for a local or remote notification.

abstract.text: Keys indicating media playback options.
Keys for retrieving text response information.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
